headline: Ham and Beans
description: This ham and beans recipe combines great northern beans with leftover diced ham, onion, brown sugar, and spices, for a comforting and delicious meal.

video.description: Great Northern beans are simmered with ham, onion, brown sugar, and spices.
video.name: Ham and Beans

name: Ham and Beans
recipeIngredient: 6 cups water, or as needed to cover

recipeInstructions.text: Rinse beans; transfer to a large stockpot. Cover with cold water and let stand overnight or at least 8 hours. Drain and rinse beans.

Return beans to stockpot; add ham, onion, sugar, parsley, and cayenne pepper. Pour in enough water to cover and season with salt and pepper. Bring to a boil; reduce heat to low and simmer until beans are tender, adding more water if needed, about 1 1/2 to 2 hours.

review.reviewBody: I loved it. I used red pepper flakes sparingly. Super tasty. We used a crock pot and soked beans overnight, then out other ingredients in the morning. Go to work, and bam, dinner is ready. Corn bread is also necessary to make this a 10.

I have never had beans and ham before. This recipe was so delicious and so easy. I followed it to the letter although I may have put a tad less pepper than it called for. I highly recommend it. I am enclosing a picture of it cooking down, but I could not resist tasting before it was finished. I may have added a bit too much water therefore, I’m letting it cut down further.

I make this every year after Thanksgiving for the past many years. Love it with cornbread. I think I cut brown sugar in half and add heat. I'm a Texas boy. I also use honey baked ham and bone when cooking. The best ham and beans ever. Thank you. People keep asking me to make every year. Do it only once a year and they come running

Great, but added extras. I rendered the fat off a pork loin in a pot seasoned with a mirepoix ( 1 cup chopped sweet onions, carrots, celery). Strained and set aside. SImmered beans in low sodium chicken stock, a cup of brown sugar, and added 3 cups of the rendered liquid. I placed small chunks of the loin in the beans about halfway through the bean simmer and later sliced carrots. Adding the extra sugar made it appealing to those with a sweeter tooth.
I love the recipe , after reading some reviews i decided to change somethings. Being from California i added a can of Ortega peppers and half the sugar and a little more garlic and it was amazing
excellent in fact i plan to make it tomorrow. even my wife likes it
Real good!!! Best ham and beans that I’ve ever had.
This is my go to recipe for ham and beans.

I read the comments and reduced the sugar by half, it was still too sweet. I even used chicken broth and added more at the end, but the sweetness persisted. If you are looking for good old fashioned soup beans this isn't the recipe for that.

I must say, an excellent recipe. I used 5 bay leaves, 1 tbsp Liquid Smoke, 1/2 tsp Baking Soda and some Olive Oil. I skipped on the Cayenne. Excellent flavor. The brown sugar really ties everything in. Merry Christmas and Happy Hanukkah everyone.
I used chicken stock instead of water. Adds a little more flavor. Used less brown sugar and less Cheyenne pepper. Very good recipe
Way too sweet! The brown sugar is overpowering to the point it is not edible. I think everything else would be fine on its own.

Well except for the brown sugar, cayenne and parsley it's pretty much the recipe that's printed on the bag of beans. Or possibly was printed on the beans bag. I think it's pretty good no matter what you choose to put in it besides the basic 3 or 4 ingredients.

This is an easy, wholesome and generally nutritious recipe. I instinctively cut back on the brown sugar and I'm glad I did. It is missing a flavor note, to be honest. I'm wondering if it needs a couple teaspoons of garlic, but it's missing something. This can be made for about $4 which is a bonus.
I think the recipe would of be fine, if there was no sugar added. The sugar ruined it.

An alternative to soaking overnight and a tip to prevent gas:
Bring beans to a boil.
Toss in a teaspoon of baking soda (it will fizz up!) stir & turn off for an hour. The baking soda gets rid of "gasiness" beans create.
Drain the water & replace with fresh water or broth.
Do NOT use cold water or your beans will split.
Simple recipe that can be tweaked any way you want to make it your own. I add way more ham and about 25% of the brown sugar to make it perfect for my taste.

Turned out fantastic! I followed the suggestion of the other reviews and cut the brown sugar in half. I did use more ham than the recipe called for (I was using up leftover Christmas ham that I had froze). I also added 2 chicken bullion cubes. I did not soak my beans overnight, I used my instant pot to do a soak right before cooking. This will be our go to ham and beans recipe!

Very tasty! I doubled the recipe, omitted the cayenne since I’m the only one in my family that likes spicy things. I used a ham bone leftover from Thanksgiving too. I cooked it for almost 5 hrs. I like to add a half cup or so of barley the last half hour to thicken it up a bit. I’ll be making my ham and beans like this from here on out.
Excellent meal! It also pairs well serving it over rice.
I reduced the brown sugar, and increased the volume of onion and ham. It came out with a great texture, just like I was hoping!
This was really good . . . just like mom used to make! I did cut back on the sugar and added extra ham, just because I had extra, but otherwise followed the recipe.
Cut down on brown sugar, used diced buffet ham, but also threw in a couple smoked ham hocks!! Delicious!!

Ham and beans are one of my favorite easy recipes! Tonight I made it with beef broth and I think it was better than the chicken stock standby I have always enjoyed.
BIG SECRET though: chop some onions in a little vinegar and sugar and use on top as a condiment and you might think you’ve gone to heaven!

We had never used brown sugar or cayenne in our ham and beans and were very happy with the added flavor they both brought to this dish. Will definitely use this recipe again the next time we make H&B again.
Fiancé says it Good. Tasty - I’d cut back on the sugar as he tends to like savory dishes. Would probably make without sugar next time, but I do think this is a keeper.
Nice brown sugar. Not enough. Too much pepper. Just skip it. Smell is disgusting. And that is before you eat it. Pass on this one.

Followed the recipe and it turned out great. I only had fresh parsley on hand, not dried, so I chopped that up and it made the beans so delicious and herb-y tasting. I did reduce the brown sugar to 3 tbsp. I wanted my beans sweet because obviously this recipe is supposed to be on the sweet side. I feel like, while most people don't like to add sugar, with this the brown sugar emphasizes the ham flavor. Makes it reminiscent of a honeybaked ham taste. But if you don't add sugar, it becomes a more savory dish. I wanted to follow the recipe as it was intended to taste.
The brown sugar taste witha hint of the spice.
Recipe is great the only thing that I did differently was to use a crockpot.

It smelled wonderful while cooking, and my son who has aversions to a lot of foods ate a bowl without complaint and even said it was good.
I try to follow a recipe as close as possible the first time I make it, but I was using what I had on hand. I had a ham bone left over from holiday and I boiled it and then cut the ham off the bone, using the water I boiled it in to cook the beans in. I used pinto beans, because that is what I had. I only added 1 Tablespoon of brown sugar and did not add cayenne because my son won't eat anything spicy. However, I did add garlic.
Soak those beans overnight! I did reduce the brown sugar to 1/4 cup. Set slow cooker on HIGH for 5 hrs and low for 2 hours! Perfect and great flavor. Thanks.

Family loved it
I modified a bit, from other recipes.
No salt, the ham was salty enough
1/2 t black pepper
1.5 t Parsley
1T thyme
4 cloves garlic
1/4 t ground clove
6 c water
served w cornbread and salad
Absolutely delicious. Best ham and beans I've ever had

love my ham n beans. this is close to my recipe but I add 1 whole bunch of celery chopped, only 1/4 c of brown sugar for double this recipe. plus 1 person said add ham bone? you have to have a ham bone if you ask me...plus I start with 4 slices of bacon chopped up and browned for grease and added flavor
Too sweet for my taste. Cut the brown sugar completely out and it’s delicious!
I reduced the brown sugar to 4 tbsp. (1/4 of recipe amount) and it was still very sweet. Next time I think I will leave the brown sugar out entirely, as the ham itself is sweet enough IMHO.

My family was never fond of ham and beans cause it was always bland without any flavor. So I searched out a recipe and found this and it was a hit. If I talk about making Ham and Beans they say I better make them like last time. The only time all of them were finished including leftovers. This is a recipe to save!!!
Too sweet. I added liquid smoke and ham stock just to cut the sweetness of the brown sugar. If I make this again, I may not add the sugar at all.
I made some minor changes but it turned out really delicious. the next day it was even better
Found this recipe while looking for inexpensive recipes when we were going through a difficult time. We absolutely loved it! Definitely need to follow the alterations in the comments.

This is the BEST recipe I've ever had! Wont make it any other way from now on. It's a MUST try dinner! 
A+ 10 out of 10

I used pinto beans and a leftover ham shoulder and a touch of garlic powder and cut the sugar down a bit... and it was fabulous!!! Best ham & beans recipe I've come across in a long time!!! I'm making it again tonight! :D
Pretty good and hearty. I cut the brown sugar to 2 tablespoons and added 2 tablespoons of butter. Nothing special, but okay.

I made it first just the way you suggested and it was just great, but I never could leave well enough alone.
The second time I browned the onions plus some garlic in bacon grease (sorry ya'll) before adding the beans and ham to the pot. I also substituted 1/4 cup maple syrup for the brown sugar (I was out of brown sugar) and doubled the cayenne (YEP!). It was also great this way - and it made my spice-loving husband sooooo very happy! Thanks for this wonderful recipe.
I made this before I read this recipe. Its delish! Total comfort food. I didn't have Parsley, but otherwise I made it exactly and everyone loves it! Good leftovers too:) TY

I must preface by saying I do not like bean soup or beans and ham, and never will. My husband however has asked for it for years. His mother and grandmother always made it. He loves it. Now, this recipe is crazy easy and he went nuts. Tasted better than he remembered. The only thing I changed is how I made it. I just wanted one large serving, so I used a can of cannelini beans, I had a ham steak in the freezer, so cubed that up I threw all the ingredients as written in the Instant Pot with a couple cups of water and pressure cooked for half hour. I was going to make cornbread, but he said he had to have a crusty bread, so he went to the store for a baguette. Seriously, that excited for ham and beans. He claimed it was the best most perfect ham and beans ever. His words. Then he complained about the lack of leftovers. Smh.

Great as is. We made a couple changes per our tastes like adding a can of petite diced tomatoes for acid to balance the flavor and chicken broth instead of water. Used leftover grilled ham steak since it was in the house. Love to serve it over cornbread. Sounds odd but it’s amazing that way.

I agree with a previous poster who said not to give 5 stars if you did not make the recipe as stated. 5 stars gives the impression that it is pretty perfect as is. I did make some modifications, mainly cutting down on the brown sugar to about 1 tablespoon, added a little diced carrot, and substituted a 5 pepper combination from Sam's Club instead of cayenne. With those modifications, it was PERFECT!
Very easy to make!

I made this but instead of doing the beans the way you suggested, I simply added 2 cans of white northern beans instead which greatly cut down my cooking time. I am making this for dinner again tonight with some small variations - I used 2 cans of Great Northern Beans, I cut the amount of Cayenne Pepper in half (I did not the first time and it was just too much for our taste) and I just threw all the ingredients into the crock pot and will cook on high for approximately 4 hours until it smells like time to eat! I absolutely love this recipe and it literally takes less than 5 minutes to prepare and the crock pot does all the work. I am making pudding style corn bread (adding a can of cream of corn and a bit of brown sugar) to serve with it. Thank you so much for this recipe!!

Cooked in slow cooker for 8 hours instead of letting beans soak overnight. I forgot to add the sugar, but added 2 tsp onion powder and put the onions in about 1 hour prior to serving. Turned out great!
Great recipe! Cut back a tiny bit on the brown sugar. This was an awesome meal!!

I made it as the recipe said except for the Cayanne pepper (I NEVER use the hot peppers). I did NOT like the sweetness of the dish made with the brown sugar. I prefer the beans made with ham, onion, water, salt and pepper. I will NOT use this recipe again.
Good recipe. I gave it four stars because like other reviewers, I cut the sugar in half. That was perfect. Just a hint of sweet and a hint of spice. I used leftover Christmas ham and a ham hock.

I used an eleven bean mix with split peas and grain. I cut back on the brown sugar, but then added in molasses for color and flavor. I added a quart of home canned tomato, so I didn't need additional liquid.

I always cut back on spices, so I'm still rating this recipe as excellent. I followed the recommendation of others and added about a tablespoon of brown sugar and 1/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper. You could certainly add more to taste. I also used a jar of great northern beans to be able to eat these on a weeknight. Made cornbread and it was perfect on a snowy evening!
Doubled the recipe. The whole family really enjoyed the meal. Definitely will make again.
Wife and I liked it. I followed the suggestions of others and only did 1/4 cup brown sugar, I also omitted the cayenne pepper. I may try making it again with adding some diced veggies.

This recipe is so amazing! I used half the recommended amount of brown sugar and a pinch of baking soda as others recommended in the comments. Thanks for sharing this easy and delicious recipe with us.

LIke many other reviewers we found it a bit too sweet. Upon making it a second time I cut the brown sugar in half. I also added 4-5 drop of liquid smoke to give it a bit of a smokey flavor. Much better. We will continue to make it this was from now on. 

I suspect that the amount of brown sugar in the original recipe is a hold over from the child era. Kids tend to like sweets.

we had some leftover ham so I decided to try this recipe. I only used 1 T brown sugar per some of the reviews. I used 1/4 teaspoon cayenne but found it needed more cayenne. I added another 1/4 teaspoon and still thought it could use more. Next time (there likely will be a next time) I think I will do 3/4 teaspoon total and see how that it. It would be good with greens, too.

Excellent! Tastes great, easy to make, and it even freezes well. Like many others, I cut the amount of sugar in half and for my family it was perfect, sweet but not too sweet. This recipe is definitely a keeper.

I got rave reviews for this recipe. I have to admit I found it really tasty made as listed in the recipe. The only thing I would change is just increase the cayenne a bit because I personally like the spicy!
A family favorite now! Will make again!

Very good and extremely easy. I added the left over bone from a Honey Baked Easter Ham. I didn't add the brown sugar as I was making it for someone who is diabetic. I added diced red potatoes and I cooked in a crockpot on low for about 7 hours.
Extremely SWEET, sugar ruined the dish, very "Northern / yankee" style recipe
Simple and tasty. Lots of room for alteration but it doesn't need it.
Excellent recipe and will definitely make again.....don't know if it was the brown sugar mixed with the beans and ham. but the flatulence it created is second to none....
I usually HATE ham and beans. I LOVE this recipe. I'm making it again!
Use brown sugar to your individual taste.

First off...I know this is listed under "ham soup", but this is not soup. It is Ham and Beans. This is a Southern thing for many. Serve it with cornbread and this is a classic Southern meal. I am originally from the North, but married a Southerner and have lived in the South for several years. I had to learn the "basics" of Southern cooking from his family and online. This is a basic comfort food. 
Now to the recipe, I read that some felt this was too sweet. The first time I made it I added just a shy short of 1/2 cup of Brown sugar. We had no leftovers. I made it again tonight with 1/3 cup of sugar to see if there was much difference. We didn't notice much difference in sweetness. The cayenne balances the sweetness. I added a little garlic to it as well. I made it both times in my electric pressure cooker. I'm still trying to perfect the right amount of water and timing for the recipe with the pressure cooker, but this recipe is a keeper for us. (I don't use the amount of water called for since cooking with the pressure cooker is different). The pressure cooker bypasses the need to soak the beans and makes this a fairly quick, easy, simple meal. And it's fairly cheap too. Thanks for the recipe.

Anyone who does not read even 4-5 ??reviews is just naive! Or lazy. A great basic recipe which I followed but I always do my own thing with spices anyway. We like garlic - lots of it! I followed the basic how to but used chopped white onion, 3 cloves pressed garlic, 1 bay leaf, a 1/4 tsp white pepper, 1/2 tsp baking soda (a tip gleaned from the reviews - so thanks!) and generous tablespoon of dried parsley. This suited our tastes for savory rather than sweet.

I will not make it again. It had good flavor for the base groups. It was very savory. The problem was the sugar. It made it taste odd. I would suggest adding a larger onion, more cayenne, and omit all the sugar. I was disappointed .

I give it four stars because it was just a tad sweet for us. I also substituted onion powder for the chopped onion. I used canned Great Northern Beans, and bought Honey Maple Ham from the deli and just had them cut me off a 1/2 pound chunk, so I could cube it up myself. It turned out great.
I've been making this for years. My mother in law made this as well. I NEVER added brown sugar.

Loved this recipe. Very simple but great. Used 2 cans of rinsed great northern beans because that is what I had, cooked onion and leftover ham in a little butter before adding beans and other ingredients, added a little chicken broth and decreased the brown sugar to 1/4 cup. Delicious, will definitely make again.
I made it like the recipe called for except I did not add the hotness to it as My Family can not do the spiciness but added a lil of My own flavors and they loved it

I made a double batch - doubled everything except ham and brown sugar. I used 1 1/2 pounds of ham and left the brown sugar at 1/2 cup. Threw everything in the crockpot and went to bed. Had an awesome lunch. Thanks for the recipe.

Followed some changes suggested by other reviewers. Soaked beans over night, boiled them 90 minutes and put them in crock pot with ham and onion lighted browned in butter. Reduced sugar to 1 T, added 1/2 t of baking soda and decreased cayenne pepper to 1/8 t ( I would have liked it hotter but my hubby doesn't like hot foods) I added a ham hock. covered with enough filtered water to cover and cooked on high for 3 hours then on low for 3 hours. Very good!
As others have noted, preparing according to the recipe results in a dish that is way too sweet. Next time, I'll cut the brown sugar to about 2 tablespoons.
a little less salt because beans are packed in it. Also added about 2 tsps. of brown sugar. Very good.
Simple and excelllent recipe...

Excellent with the reduction of the brown sugar by half. Any more would have tasted too much like baked beans. Added a bit of garlic powder too but I add that to everything! Thank you! I will make again. It sets itself apart from the run of the mill ham and beans.

Loved this recipe. The beans really absorb flavors unlike other beans. Used our own bone in ham which was only cured. I did take advice from others on here and reduced brown sugar to 1/4 cup, I figured if it wasn't sweet enough I would add the other 1/4 cup later. Didn't need it. Other than this I followed exactly. Didn't taste the cayenne but I will probably leave as is next time we fix this.

I used my crockpot and it turned out awesome! I didn't use the cayenne pepper due to allergies but now I'm making it again for tomorrow nights dinner and I will add the pinch of baking soda that was recommended. Love this recipe!!

I only had a half hour to dinner time.... I used 3 cans great northern beans, fried up the onions and ham together in the pan to increase flavor, then added the spices. The recipe given probably would taste more flavorful, but this quick adaption worked fine over brown rice! We like greens, so would probably add it over steamed kale with the brown rice next time.
Drop the sugar, like salty taste better
Added a little more cayenne and also I added carrots and celery. My family LOVED it!!

I altered this recipe just a little. Made this with Kielbasa instead of ham and I used only 1/3 cup of brown sugar . This was absolutely delicious !! Add a side salad and its a perfect meal !
We will make this again. 
Thank You for posting the recipe
I used a tbls of sugar and thought that was plenty. I also added a smoked ham hock because I like a smoky flavor.

I cut the sugar in half and cut the pepper even more since my wife requested those changes. It was pretty tasteless until I added some chicken bouillon. I didn't add more water, just the bouillon. Much better.

Used to eat this all the time when i was younger, its a really cheap meal to prepare and its great. I was shocked to find out my husband had never had beans prepared this way, so i fixed it for him and my whole family gobbled it up. even my picky kids. Great with cornbread. Thanks for sharing the recipe.

Several people said it was too sweet so I reduced the 1/2 cup of brown sugar to 2 heaping tbsp. Couple people said it was too hot, but I kept the cayenne pepper it called for cause I like a lil spice, and I was glad I did! I also took the advice to add 1/4 tsp of baking soda for creaminess. At the end I dissolved 2 tbsp of corn starch, using the juices from the soup, added it and let it simmer for about another 20 mins. I added 1 cup of milk at this time to add to the creaminess. I sauteed the onions like someone suggested. And instead of just dicing ham I used the whole ham hock and I added about 2 cups of diced chunks as well. The cook time said 2 hrs on the beans, I'm not sure if it's my altitude or what (9,000 ft), but it took about 3 hrs total to cook. Hope this helps. It sure is yummy!

This was surprisingly good! So much so that I'm doing my first review. :) I've not been a fan of beans and ham in the past but had extra ham we needed to use. I did a 1/4 cup of the brown sugar and it was just right. Great flavor! It reduced quickly and only took about an hour. Would definitely make it again!

Yummy and a great way to use up leftover ham! I cut way back on the sugar, as recommended by most reviewers, adding 1.5 Tbs. I sauteed the onions and a sliced carrot in 1Tbs oil and butter, until the onions were soft, before adding the remaining ingredients. Used canned beans and added a cup of cubed butternut squash and 2 tablespoons red quinoa along with the ham and beans. Added a pinch of cinnamon and 1/4 tsp ground corriander, cooked 20 minutes, and during the last 2 minutes of cooking, added 1/4 tsp baking soda to reduce gassiness from the beans (per another reviewer's suggestion), 1Tbs cornstarch to thicken the remaining liquid, and about 4 oz bean sprouts, just to use those up. A lot of changes , I know, but, other than the reduced sugar, I dont think they were absolutely necessary to make this dish delicious. This recipe is very forgiving and allows one to swap out or add veges and grains that are on-hand, and spices to taste, which makes it a great recipe! And substituting canned beans drastically reduces the cooking time and you can have the meal on the table in under 30 minutes, start to finish!
Reduced amount of sugar by half . A little sweet for me, but overall, very delicious and simple to make.
My husband and i loved this recipe. Didn't make any changes and followed the recipe exactly and he said it was the best I've ever made. Will definitely keep this one.

Amazing! It's not your traditional ham & beans, which is what I love about it. You can easily tweak it to your preference of sweetness or "heat," but I make it just as the recipe reads. And we LOVE it!!!
